"**All by Myself** " is a song by American artist [Eric
Carmen](/wiki/Eric_Carmen "Eric Carmen") released in 1975. The verse is based
on the second movement (_Adagio sostenuto_) of [Sergei
Rachmaninoff](/wiki/Sergei_Rachmaninoff "Sergei Rachmaninoff")'s _[Piano
Concerto No. 2 in C minor](/wiki/Piano_Concerto_No._2_\(Rachmaninoff\) "Piano
Concerto No. 2 \(Rachmaninoff\)")_ , Opus 18. The chorus is borrowed from the
song "[Let's Pretend](/wiki/Let%27s_Pretend_\(Raspberries_song\) "Let's
Pretend \(Raspberries song\)")", which Carmen wrote and recorded with the
[Raspberries](/wiki/Raspberries_\(band\) "Raspberries \(band\)") in 1972.[5]

The song was the first released on Carmen's [first solo
LP](/wiki/Eric_Carmen_\(1975_album\) "Eric Carmen \(1975 album\)") after
leaving the [power pop](/wiki/Power_pop "Power pop") group the
[Raspberries](/wiki/Raspberries_\(band\) "Raspberries \(band\)") and was
released as the first single in December 1975, to great acclaim. It reached
number 2 on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot
100") behind [The Miracles](/wiki/The_Miracles "The Miracles")' "[Love
Machine](/wiki/Love_Machine_\(The_Miracles_song\) "Love Machine \(The Miracles
song\)")" and [The Four Seasons](/wiki/The_Four_Seasons_\(band\) "The Four
Seasons \(band\)")' "[December, 1963 (Oh What a
Night)](/wiki/December,_1963_\(Oh,_What_a_Night\) "December, 1963 \(Oh, What a
Night\)")", number 1 on _[Cash Box](/wiki/Cash_Box "Cash Box")_ Top 100
Singles and number 3 in Canada. The single sold more than one million copies
in the United States and was certified gold by the
[RIAA](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America") in April 1976.[6] "All By Myself" was Carmen's first
of eight US Top 40 hits. In the UK, however, this was his only Top 40 success,
peaking at number 12. In a 2006 poll for UK's [Five](/wiki/Channel_5_\(UK\)
"Channel 5 \(UK\)") programme _Britain 's Favourite Break-up Songs_, Eric
Carmen's version of this song was voted seventeenth.

Rachmaninoff's music was in the [public domain](/wiki/Public_domain "Public
domain") in the United States and Carmen thought no copyright existed on it,
but it was still protected outside the U.S. Subsequent to the release of the
album, he was contacted by the Rachmaninoff estate and informed otherwise.[7]
An agreement was reached in which the estate would receive 12 percent of the
royalties from "All by Myself" as well as from "[Never Gonna Fall in Love
Again](/wiki/Never_Gonna_Fall_in_Love_Again "Never Gonna Fall in Love
Again")", which was based on the third movement from Rachmaninoff's _[Symphony
No. 2](/wiki/Symphony_No._2_\(Rachmaninoff\) "Symphony No. 2
\(Rachmaninoff\)")_.[8][9]

Carmen has stated that he also incorporated part of another melody into this
song. The melody was taken from his previous hit with the
[Raspberries](/wiki/Raspberries_\(band\) "Raspberries \(band\)"), "[Let's
Pretend](/wiki/Let%27s_Pretend_\(Raspberries_song\) "Let's Pretend
\(Raspberries song\)")."[10]

Carmen's original version has spawned numerous cover versions by such artists
as [Rico J. Puno](/wiki/Rico_J._Puno "Rico J. Puno") in 1976, [Celine
Dion](/wiki/Celine_Dion "Celine Dion") in 1996, [Frank
Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), [Igudesman &
Joo](/wiki/Igudesman_%26_Joo "Igudesman & Joo"), [Il Divo](/wiki/Il_Divo "Il
Divo"), and [Only Men Aloud!](/wiki/Only_Men_Aloud! "Only Men Aloud!").

The slide guitar solo was performed by famed studio guitarist [Hugh
McCracken](/wiki/Hugh_McCracken "Hugh McCracken").[11]

## Television
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=All_by_Myself&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Television performance")]

Carmen performed "All By Myself" and his follow-up hit, "Never Gonna Fall in
Love Again," on _[The Midnight
Special](/wiki/The_Midnight_Special_\(TV_series\) "The Midnight Special \(TV
series\)")_ television program on July 23, 1976 (season 4, episode 37). The
show was hosted by [The Spinners](/wiki/The_Spinners_\(American_R%26B_group\)
"The Spinners \(American R&B group\)").[12]

One of the most notable cover versions of "All by Myself" was recorded by
[Celine Dion](/wiki/Celine_Dion "Celine Dion") in 1996. It was the fourth (or
third, depending on the country) hit [single](/wiki/Single_\(music\) "Single
\(music\)") from her album _[Falling into You](/wiki/Falling_into_You "Falling
into You")_.[29] Produced by [David Foster](/wiki/David_Foster "David Foster")
at [Compass Point Studios](/wiki/Compass_Point_Studios "Compass Point
Studios") in [The Bahamas](/wiki/The_Bahamas "The Bahamas"), it was released
on October 7, 1996 in Europe, January 13, 1997 in Australia, and March 11,
1997 in North America.

There were three music videos made. The first one was released in October
1996. It contains fragments from Dion's photo session for the _Falling into
You_ album cover and some scenes from her _[Live à
Paris](/wiki/Live_%C3%A0_Paris "Live à Paris")_ concert. It was made for the
single version and it was directed by Nigel Dick. The second version was made
for the UK market with the same white T-shirt scenes but adding footage of a
young couple in love at Christmas time, instead of scenes from Dion's concert.
This was made for the album version. Finally, a live music video was released
in March 1997 in North America (from the 1996 concert in Montreal).

Dion performed this song many times during world tours, TV shows and music
events such as the [Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") (1997),
[Billboard Music Awards](/wiki/Billboard_Music_Award "Billboard Music Award")
(1997) and [Bambi Awards](/wiki/Bambi_\(prize\) "Bambi \(prize\)") (1996). A
performance from her 2008-2009 [Taking Chances Tour](/wiki/Taking_Chances_Tour
"Taking Chances Tour") can be found on the _[Taking Chances World Tour: The
Concert](/wiki/Taking_Chances_World_Tour:_The_Concert "Taking Chances World
Tour: The Concert")_ DVD/CD. It is currently included in the set list of
Dion's Las Vegas residency show [Céline](/wiki/Celine_\(residency_show\)
"Celine \(residency show\)") which premiered on March 15, 2011. The song was
also performed during the 2013 [Sans attendre Tour](/wiki/Sans_attendre_Tour
"Sans attendre Tour"); the Quebec City performance was included in the
_[Céline... une seule fois / Live
2013](/wiki/C%C3%A9line..._une_seule_fois_/_Live_2013 "Céline... une seule
fois / Live 2013")_ CD/DVD.[30] The song was also performed in Dion's [2017
European tour](/wiki/Celine_Dion_Live_2017 "Celine Dion Live 2017").

Dion also recorded a [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language")
version of "All by Myself," called "Sola otra vez"
([English](/wiki/English_language "English language"): _By Myself Again_). It
was added to the _Falling into You_ Latin American/Spanish edition, and as a
B-side to other singles from that album. This version became available
worldwide on Dion's later compilation _[The Collector's Series, Volume
One](/wiki/The_Collector%27s_Series,_Volume_One "The Collector's Series,
Volume One")_. The CD single was released in 1996 in Brazil only. Dion's "Sola
otra vez" was selected the number one Spanish language cover of an English pop
song by TheSpanishVersion.Org.[31]

The "All by Myself" single became one of Dion's biggest hits in the United
States, reaching number 1 on the [Hot Adult Contemporary
Tracks](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult Contemporary \(chart\)")
(for three weeks) and the [Latin Pop Airplay](/wiki/Latin_Pop_Airplay "Latin
Pop Airplay") (two weeks). It peaked at number 4 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") (number 7 on the [Billboard
Hot 100 Airplay](/wiki/Hot_100_Airplay_\(Radio_Songs\) "Hot 100 Airplay
\(Radio Songs\)") and number 5 on the [Hot 100 Singles
Sales](/wiki/Hot_100_Singles_Sales "Hot 100 Singles Sales")). It was also a
top 10 hit in France, United Kingdom, Wallonia in Belgium and the Republic of
Ireland. In Canada, "All by Myself" was released as a promotional single only,
hitting number 1 on the Adult Contemporary Chart. "All by Myself" was
certified gold in the US (500,000), and silver in the UK (200,000) and France
(165,000).

The track was included on some editions of Dion's greatest hits _[All the
Way... A Decade of Song](/wiki/All_the_Way..._A_Decade_of_Song "All the Way...
A Decade of Song")_ in 1999 and on _[My Love: Essential
Collection](/wiki/My_Love:_Essential_Collection "My Love: Essential
Collection")_ in 2008.

This version also features on the [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_channel\) "ITV \(TV
channel\)") game show _[Take Me Out](/wiki/Take_Me_Out_\(UK_game_show\) "Take
Me Out \(UK game show\)")_ if the contestant leaves the show without a date.

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=All_by_Myself&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Critical reception")]

Dion's cover received positive reviews. _New York Times_ editor Stephen Holden
wrote that the remake, along with "Because You Loved Me," "are the strongest
cuts on an album crammed with formulaic romantic bombast."[32] Dave Sholin
from the _[Gavin Report](/wiki/Gavin_Report "Gavin Report")_ commented:
"Demand by both programmers and the public for this rendition of Eric Carmen's
1976 smash made it the obvious choice to be the third single lifted off
Celine's multi-platinum and Grammy-nominated album, Falling Into You."[33]
Music.uk.launch.yahoo.com editor Dan Leroy wrote: "Trying to out-emote Eric
Carmen was almost crazy enough to work."[34] _Entertainment Weekly_ editor
Chuck Eddy said:" ...But only in her desolate cover of Eric Carmen's _All by
Myself_ does she truly crash through the glass ceiling of passion."[35]

## Other cover
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=All_by_Myself&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Other cover versions")]

In 1994, "All By Myself" was covered by New Zealand singer [Margaret
Urlich](/wiki/Margaret_Urlich "Margaret Urlich"). Her version reached #100 in
Australia in November 1994,[75] and #26 in New Zealand in March 1995.[76]

The 2001 motion picture _[Bridget Jones's
Diary](/wiki/Bridget_Jones%27s_Diary_\(film\) "Bridget Jones's Diary
\(film\)")_ featured a cover version performed by [Jamie
O'Neal](/wiki/Jamie_O%27Neal "Jamie O'Neal")[77] showing actress [Renée
Zellweger](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9e_Zellweger "Renée Zellweger") singing to it in the
famous pajamas scene. This track is also played over the other Bridget Jones
films _[Bridget Jones: The Edge of
Reason](/wiki/Bridget_Jones:_The_Edge_of_Reason_\(film\) "Bridget Jones: The
Edge of Reason \(film\)")_ and _[Bridget Jones's
Baby](/wiki/Bridget_Jones%27s_Baby "Bridget Jones's Baby")_.

In 2008, the male voice choir [Only Men Aloud!](/wiki/Only_Men_Aloud! "Only
Men Aloud!") covered the song on their [self-named
album](/wiki/Only_Men_Aloud!_\(album\) "Only Men Aloud! \(album\)") and also
released it as a single.

## Use in popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=All_by_Myself&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Use in popular culture")]

The Carmen version is used in the video introduction for [Conan
O'Brien](/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien "Conan O'Brien")'s "[Legally Prohibited from
Being Funny on Television
Tour](/wiki/The_Legally_Prohibited_from_Being_Funny_on_Television_Tour "The
Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour")", when an obese and
bearded version of the talk show host struggles to cope with losing his job as
host of _[Tonight Show](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Conan_O%27Brien "The
Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien")_. The Carmen version is also featured in the
second season's episode 17 of the popular 1990s sitcom
_[Friends](/wiki/Friends "Friends")_ (set on [Joey](/wiki/Joey_Tribbiani "Joey
Tribbiani") & [Chandler's](/wiki/Chandler_Bing "Chandler Bing") friendship),
and a season 4 episode of the hit sitcom _[That'70s
Show](/wiki/That_%2770s_Show "That '70s Show")_ whereas [Eric
Forman](/wiki/Eric_Forman "Eric Forman") breaks up with [Donna
Pinciotti](/wiki/Donna_Pinciotti "Donna Pinciotti"). It was also featured in
the films _[Under Wraps](/wiki/Under_Wraps_\(film\) "Under Wraps \(film\)")_ ,
_[Bridget Jones' Diary](/wiki/Bridget_Jones%27s_Diary_\(film\) "Bridget
Jones's Diary \(film\)")_ and _[To Die For](/wiki/To_Die_For "To Die For")_.
The version is used also in the film _[I nuovi mostri](/wiki/I_nuovi_mostri "I
nuovi mostri")_ directed by [Dino Risi](/wiki/Dino_Risi "Dino Risi"), with
[Ornella Muti](/wiki/Ornella_Muti "Ornella Muti") and [Yorgo
Voyagis](/wiki/Yorgo_Voyagis "Yorgo Voyagis"). In the Disney film
_[Zootopia](/wiki/Zootopia "Zootopia")_ , a snippet is heard of it as the main
character, Judy Hopps, browses through one depressing song after another on
her clock radio.

A character is featured performing the song as karaoke in the 2001
_[Angel](/wiki/Angel_\(1999_TV_series\) "Angel \(1999 TV series\)")_ episode
"[Happy Anniversary](/wiki/Happy_Anniversary_\(Angel\) "Happy Anniversary
\(Angel\)")".

The song was used in advertisements:

  * [Toyota Soarer](/wiki/Toyota_Soarer "Toyota Soarer"), Japan, 1991
  * [Honda CR-V](/wiki/Honda_CR-V "Honda CR-V") Second Generation, Thailand, 2002
  * [Visine](/wiki/Visine "Visine") "Distance" version, Indonesia, 2011
